text: basic example shows solve common problem: special using README.Rmd instead just README.md? can include R chunks like : ’ll still need render README.Rmd regularly, keep README.md --date. devtools::build_readme() handy . can also embed plots, example:  case, don’t forget commit push resulting figure files, display GitHub CRAN.
code: library(bregr) ## basic example code summary(cars) #>      speed           dist        #>  Min.   : 4.0   Min.   :  2.00   #>  1st Qu.:12.0   1st Qu.: 26.00   #>  Median :15.0   Median : 36.00   #>  Mean   :15.4   Mean   : 42.98   #>  3rd Qu.:19.0   3rd Qu.: 56.00   #>  Max.   :25.0   Max.   :120.00

title: Data accessors — accessors
text: Accessors breg objects. Functions addtional arguments provide additional functionality.

title: Data accessors — accessors
code: br_get_data(obj)  br_get_y(obj)  br_get_x(obj)  br_get_n_x(obj)  br_get_n_x2(obj)  br_get_x2(obj)  br_get_group_by(obj)  br_get_config(obj)  br_get_models(obj)  br_get_model(obj, idx)  br_get_results(obj, tidy = FALSE, ...)

title: Data accessors — accessors
text: idx Index names (focal variables) model(s) return. tidy TRUE return tidy (compact) results, otherwise return comprehensive results. tidy results obtained broom::tidy() comprehensive results obtained broom.helpers::tidy_plus_plus(). results can configured run br_run(). ... Subset operations passing dplyr::filter() filter results.

title: Show model tidy results in table format — br_show_table
text: breg object class breg results. ... Arguments passing br_get_results() subsetting table. args_table_format list arguments passing insight::format_table(). export Logical. TRUE, show table export purpose, e.g., present table Markdown HTML format. args_table_export list arguments passing insight::export_table(). works export TRUE.

title: New breg-class object — breg
text: New breg-class object

title: New breg-class object — breg
code: breg(   y = NULL,   x = NULL,   x2 = NULL,   group_by = NULL,   data = NULL,   config = NULL,   models = list(),   results = NULL,   results_tidy = NULL )

title: New breg-class object — breg
text: y Character vector representing dependent variables. x Character vector representing focal variables. x2 Character vector representing control variables, optional. group_by Character vector representing group column, optional. data data.frame containing data modeling. config Configurations model construction. models List model. results data.frame containing result data models (broom.helpers::tidy_plus_plus()). results_tidy data.frame containing tidy result data models (broom::tidy()).

title: New breg-class object — breg
code: obj <- breg("y", letters[1:5], LETTERS[1:5]) obj #> A object of <breg> class with slots: #> • y (response variable): y #> • x (focal terms): a, b, c, d, and e #> • x2 (control terms): A, B, C, D, and E #> • group_by: #> • data: <df[,0]> #> • config: #> • models: <list: > #> • results: <df[,0]> #> • results_tidy: <df[,0]> #>  #> Focal term(s) are injected into the model one by one, #> while control term(s) remain constant across all models in the batch. print(obj, raw = TRUE) #> <bregr::breg> #>  @ y           : chr "y" #>  @ x           : chr [1:5] "a" "b" "c" "d" "e" #>  @ x2          : chr [1:5] "A" "B" "C" "D" "E" #>  @ group_by    : NULL #>  @ data        :'data.frame':	0 obs. of  0 variables #>  @ config      : NULL #>  @ models      : list() #>  @ results     :'data.frame':	0 obs. of  0 variables #>  @ results_tidy:'data.frame':	0 obs. of  0 variables #>  @ n_x         : int 5 #>  @ n_x2        : int 5 #> NULL

what: bregr: Easy and Efficient Batch Processing of Regression Models in R — bregr-package
title: bregr: Easy and Efficient Batch Processing of Regression Models in R — bregr-package
text: Easily process batches univariate multivariate regression models. Returns results tidy format generates visualization plots straightforward interpretation.

title: bregr: Easy and Efficient Batch Processing of Regression Models in R — bregr-package
text: Maintainer: Shixiang Wang w_shixiang@163.com (ORCID) Authors: Yun Peng yunyunp96@163.com (ORCID) Chenyang Shu 402221506@qq.com

title: Modeling and analysis pipeline — pipeline
text: br_pipeline(): --one end end wrapper run regression analysis batch. splitted following steps: br_set_data(): Set data model construction. br_set_y(): Set dependent variables model construction. br_set_x(): Set focal terms model construction. br_set_x2(): (Optional) Set control terms model construction. br_set_model(): Set model configurations. br_run(): Run regression analysis batch.

title: Modeling and analysis pipeline — pipeline
code: br_pipeline(   data,   y,   x,   method,   x2 = NULL,   group_by = NULL,   run_parallel = 1L,   model_args = list(),   run_args = list() )  br_set_data(data)  br_set_y(obj, y)  br_set_x(obj, ...)  br_set_x2(obj, ...)  br_set_model(obj, method, ...)  br_run(obj, ..., group_by = NULL, run_parallel = 1L)

title: Modeling and analysis pipeline — pipeline
text: data data.frame containing necessary variables analysis. Column names follow R's naming conventions. y Character vector specifying dependent variables (response variables). GLM models, typically single character (e.g., "outcome"). Cox-PH models, length-2 vector format c("time", "status"). x Character vector specifying focal independent terms (predictors). method Method model construction. x2 Character vector specifying control independent terms (predictor, optional). group_by string specifying group column. run_parallel Integer, indicating cores run task, default 1. model_args list arguments passed br_set_model(). run_args list arguments passed br_run(). obj object class breg. ... Additional arguments depending called function. br_set_x() passing focal terms characters. br_set_x2() passing control terms characters. br_set_model() passing configurations modeling. br_run() passing configurations obtaining modeling results tidy_plus_plus(). e.g., default value exponentiate FALSE (coefficients exponentiated). logistic, multinomial, Cox-PH regressions models, exponentiate typically set TRUE. generate resonable results, arguments reset, include: intercept: TRUE (default) (instead FALSE default tidy_plus_plus()).

title: Modeling and analysis pipeline — pipeline
text: Please note difference variables terms, e.g., x + poly(x, 2) one variable x, two terms x poly(x, 2).

title: Modeling and analysis pipeline — pipeline
code: library(bregr) # 1. Pipeline ------------------------- # 1.1. A single linear model ---------- m <- br_set_data(mtcars) |> # set model data   br_set_y("mpg") |> # set dependent variable   br_set_x("qsec") |> # set focal variables   br_set_model("gaussian") |> # set model   br_run() # run analysis  # get model tidy result br_get_results(m, tidy = TRUE) #> # A tibble: 2 × 8 #>   Focal_variable term    estimate std.error statistic p.value conf.low conf.high #>   <chr>          <chr>      <dbl>     <dbl>     <dbl>   <dbl>    <dbl>     <dbl> #> 1 qsec           (Inter…    -5.11    10.0      -0.510  0.614   -24.8       14.5  #> 2 qsec           qsec        1.41     0.559     2.53   0.0171    0.316      2.51 # or m@results_tidy  # compare with R's built-in function lm(mpg ~ qsec, data = mtcars) |> summary() #>  #> Call: #> lm(formula = mpg ~ qsec, data = mtcars) #>  #> Residuals: #>     Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max  #> -9.8760 -3.4539 -0.7203  2.2774 11.6491  #>  #> Coefficients: #>             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)   #> (Intercept)  -5.1140    10.0295  -0.510   0.6139   #> qsec          1.4121     0.5592   2.525   0.0171 * #> --- #> Signif. codes:  0 ‘***’ 0.001 ‘**’ 0.01 ‘*’ 0.05 ‘.’ 0.1 ‘ ’ 1 #>  #> Residual standard error: 5.564 on 30 degrees of freedom #> Multiple R-squared:  0.1753,	Adjusted R-squared:  0.1478  #> F-statistic: 6.377 on 1 and 30 DF,  p-value: 0.01708 #>  # 1.2. Batch linear model ------------- # control variables are injected in all constructed models # focal variables are injected in constructed models one by one m2 <- br_set_data(mtcars) |>   br_set_y("mpg") |>   br_set_x(colnames(mtcars)[2:4]) |> # set focal variables   br_set_x2("vs") |> # set control variables   br_set_model("gaussian") |>   br_run() # 1.3. Group by model ------------- m3 <- br_set_data(mtcars) |>   br_set_y("mpg") |>   br_set_x("cyl") |>   br_set_x2("wt") |> # set control variables   br_set_model("gaussian") |>   br_run(group_by = "am")  # 2. All-in-one pipeline wrapper --- m4 <- br_pipeline(mtcars,   y = "mpg",   x = colnames(mtcars)[2:4],   x2 = "vs",   method = "gaussian" )
